tit.cmt: 定訳のところにYasuyuki Toki's rebellionとありますが、ネット上で見る限りToki Yasuyuki Rebellionの方が使用例が多い(大塩平八郎の乱なども同様）く、使いやすいようにも思えるので変更しました。

sen.j: 土岐康行の乱（ときやすゆきのらん）は、室町時代の康応元年（1389年）－明徳元年（1390年）に守護大名の土岐康行が室町幕府に討伐された事件である。
sen.e: Yasuyuki TOKI's rebellion was the incident that Yasuyuki TOKI, shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords), was put down by Muromachi bakufu from 1389 to 1390 of Muromachi Period.

Toki Yasuyori Rebellion was an incident that occurred from 1389 to 1390, during the Muromachi period of Japan, in which Yasuyuki TOKI, a shugo daimyo (shugo is a governor of a province during the middle ages of Japan, and a shugo daimyo is a regional lord who has an official title of shugo from the government of the time) was defeated by the Muromachi bakufu.

Toki Yasuyori Rebellion was an incident that occurred from 1389 to 1390, during the Muromachi period of Japan, in which Yasuyuki TOKI, a shugo daimyo (shugo is a governor of a province during the middle ages of Japan, and a shugo daimyo is a regional lord who has an official title of shugo from the government of the time) was defeated by the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: 美濃の乱とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It was also called the rebellion of Mino Province.
It was also called the rebellion of Mino Province.
It was also called the rebellion of Mino Province.

sen.j: 土岐氏
sen.e: The Toki clan
The Toki clan
The Toki clan

sen.j: 美濃源氏の土岐氏は美濃国で大きな勢力を有し鎌倉幕府の有力御家人となった。
sen.e: The Toki clan, which descended from Mino-Genji, had a huge power in Mino Province and became senior vassals of Kamakura bakufu.
The Toki clan, which descended from Mino-Genji, had a huge power in Mino Province and became a senior vassal of the Kamakura bakufu.
The Toki clan, which descended from Mino-Genji, had a huge power in Mino Province and became a senior vassal of the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 土岐頼貞は南北朝時代 (日本)では北朝 (日本)について室町幕府から美濃守護職に任じられ、足利尊氏を助けて功績が大きく幕府創業の功臣となった。
sen.e: Yorisada TOKI took sides with Northern Courts (Japan) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) and was appointed as Mino shugoshiki (military governor of Mino Province) by Muromachi bakufu and helped Takauji ASHIKAGA, after that, he became a meritorious retainer by his a great achievement when bakufu was established.

Yorisada TOKI took sides with the Northern Court during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts of Japan, and was appointed as Mino shugoshiki (military governor of Mino Province) by the Muromachi bakufu for helping Takauji ASHIKAGA; after that, he became one of the meritorious vassals for his great achievement when the bakufu was established.

Yorisada TOKI took sides with the Northern Court during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts of Japan, and was appointed as Mino shugoshiki (military governor of Mino Province) by the Muromachi bakufu for helping Takauji ASHIKAGA; after that, he became one of the meritorious vassals for his great achievement when the bakufu was established.

sen.j: その孫の土岐頼康は美濃国・尾張国・伊勢国の3ヵ国の守護に任ぜられて評定衆に連なり、土岐氏の最盛期を築いた。
sen.e: His grandchild, Yoriyasu TOKI, was appointed to shugo of three provinces: Mino, Owari and Ise, equals to hyojoshu (a member of Council of state), and established the golden age of the Toki clan.
His grandchild, Yoriyasu TOKI, became the shugo of three provinces: Mino, Owari and Ise, and became one of the hyojoshu (members of the Council of State) to establish the golden age of the Toki clan.
His grandchild, Yoriyasu TOKI, became the shugo of three provinces: Mino, Owari and Ise, and became one of the hyojoshu (members of the Council of State) to establish the golden age of the Toki clan.

sen.j: 三代征夷大将軍足利義満の時、頼康は管領細川頼之と不和になって勝手に帰国してしまい、義満を激怒させ討伐令を出されたことがある（後に謝罪して許された）。
sen.e: In the period, when the 3rd Seiitaishogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA controlled, Yoriyasu returned home at his discretion because of the feud with Shogunal Deputy Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, and it made Yoshimitsu angry, so Yoshimitsu commanded to put down Yoriyasu (he apologized his behavior and was forgiven later).

During the period, under the third shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, Yoriyasu invoked the wrath of Yoshimitsu because he returned to his own province without permission due to a feud with Shogunal Deputy Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, and Yoshimitsu even issued a punitive order (later, Yoriyasu apologized was forgiven).

During the period, under the third shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, Yoriyasu invoked the wrath of Yoshimitsu because he returned to his own province without permission due to a feud with Shogunal Deputy Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, and Yoshimitsu even issued a punitive order (later, Yoriyasu apologized was forgiven).

sen.j: 康暦元年（1379年）の康暦の政変では斯波義将とともに細川頼之排斥に動いている。
sen.e: In Koryaku Coup occurred in 1379, Yoriyasu tried to turn away Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA together with Yoshimasa SHIBA.
In the Koryaku Coup, occurred in 1379, Yoriyasu worked with Yoshimasa SHIBA to expel Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA.
In the Koryaku Coup, occurred in 1379, Yoriyasu worked with Yoshimasa SHIBA to expel Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 頼康は幕府創業以来の宿老として重きをおいた。
sen.e: Yoriyasu was an important person as chief vassal since bakufu was established.
Yoriyasu sustained a certain power as one of the chief vassals from the beginning of the bakufu.
sen.cmt: この時期の重臣はこの人だけではないので、各所で、one of the….と表現しました。
sen.e: Yoriyasu sustained a certain power as one of the chief vassals from the beginning of the bakufu.

sen.j: 乱の経緯
sen.e: Progress of the rebellion
Development of the rebellion
Development of the rebellion

sen.j: 嘉慶 (日本)元年（1387年）頼康が70歳の高齢で死去。
sen.e: In 1387, Yoriyasu died at advanced age of 70 years old.
In 1387, Yoriyasu died at 70 years old, an advanced age of the time.
In 1387, Yoriyasu died at 70 years old, an advanced age of the time.

sen.j: 土岐氏の惣領は養子の康行が継いだ。
sen.e: Yasuyuki, an adopted son of Yoriyasu, succeeded Soryo (heir) of the Toki clan.
Yasuyuki, an adopted son of Yoriyasu, became the soryo (heir, or head of the chief branch of the family) of the Toki clan.
Yasuyuki, an adopted son of Yoriyasu, became the soryo (heir, or head of the chief branch of the family) of the Toki clan.

sen.j: 康行は従兄弟の土岐詮直を尾張守護代とし、弟の土岐満貞を京都代官として義満に近侍させた。
sen.e: Yasuyuki appointed his cousin named Akinao TOKI to a guard of Owari, and his brother named Mitsusada TOKI to Kyoto daikan (the regional officer of Kyoto) to attend Yoshimitsu.

Yasuyuki appointed his cousin Akinao TOKI to a guard of Owari, and sent his brother Mitsusada TOKI as a daikan (local governor) of Kyoto, where the bakufu existed, to attend Yoshimitsu in a short distance.

Yasuyuki appointed his cousin Akinao TOKI to a guard of Owari, and sent his brother Mitsusada TOKI as a daikan (local governor) of Kyoto, where the bakufu existed, to attend Yoshimitsu in a short distance.

sen.j: 将軍専制権力の確立を目指す義満は統制が困難だった有力守護大名の弱体化を狙っていた。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu aimed to establish the authority of shogun tyranny, therefore he required of weaken of the power of the dominant Shugo Guardian Feudal Lord, which was difficult to control.
At that time, Yoshimitsu wanted to make the shogunate an autocratic power, and thus he aimed to weaken major shugo clans, whom he had trouble to control.
At that time, Yoshimitsu wanted to make the shogunate an autocratic power, and thus he aimed to weaken major shugo clans, whom he had trouble to control.

sen.j: 嘉慶2年（1388年）義満は美濃国、伊勢国の守護職の継承のみを康行に許し、尾張国は満貞に与えてしまった。
sen.e: In 1388, Yoshimitsu allowed Yasuyuki to succeed only shugoshiki of Mino Province and Ise Province, and as for Owari Province, he gave it Mitsusada.
In 1388, Yoshimitsu allowed Yasuyuki to succeed the entitlement of shugoshiki only for Mino Province and Ise Province, and he gave the one for Owari Provide to Mitsusada.
In 1388, Yoshimitsu allowed Yasuyuki to succeed the entitlement of shugoshiki only for Mino Province and Ise Province, and he gave the one for Owari Provide to Mitsusada.

sen.j: 満貞は野心家で尾張守護職を欲して度々義満へ康行と詮直の讒言をしていた。
sen.e: Mitsusada was an ambitious person and wanted to be shugoshiki of Owari Province, so he often said to Yoshimitsu bad things about Yasuyuki and Akinao.
Mitsusada was an ambitious person and wanted to have the shugoshiki of Owari Province, so he pandered to Yoshimitsu, making false accusations against Yasuyuki and Akinao.
Mitsusada was an ambitious person and wanted to have the shugoshiki of Owari Province, so he pandered to Yoshimitsu, making false accusations against Yasuyuki and Akinao.

sen.j: 義満はこの兄弟の不和を利用して土岐氏の分裂を図ったのである。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu tried to split in the Toki clan using the feud between them.
Yoshimitsu used the feud between them to split the Toki clan.
Yoshimitsu used the feud between them to split the Toki clan.

sen.j: これに激怒したのが尾張守護代の詮直で、満貞は尾張国へ下向するがこれを拒んで尾張国黒田宿で合戦になり、満貞は敗れて敗走した。
sen.e: Akinao raged this and refused that Mitsusada went to Owari Province, therefore the battle broke out between them, with the result that Yoshimitsu was defeated and run away.

Akinao, a deputy shugo, got raged with anger over the treatment, and refused Mitsusada, who came down to Owari to assume the shugo position; it eventually caused a battle between them in Kuroda juku, Owari Province and Mitusada was put to rout.
sen.cmt: 守護代、合戦の場所が抜けてます。
sen.e: Akinao, a deputy shugo, got raged with anger over the treatment, and refused Mitsusada, who came down to Owari to assume the shugo position; it eventually caused a battle between them in Kuroda juku, Owari Province and Mitusada was put to rout.

sen.j: 京へ逃げ帰った満貞は康行と詮直の謀叛を訴えた。
sen.e: Mitsusada fled from the battlefield and came back to the capital, and appealed to Yoshimitsu about Yasuyuki and Akinao's rebellion.
Mitsusada fled from the battlefield and came back to the capital, and appealed to Yoshimitsu about Yasuyuki and Akinao's rebellion.
Mitsusada fled from the battlefield and came back to the capital, and appealed to Yoshimitsu about Yasuyuki and Akinao's rebellion.

sen.j: 義満はこの機を逃さず、康応元年（1389年）4月に康行を謀反人と断じて討伐を命じ、土岐氏一族の土岐頼忠・土岐頼益父子が征討に向かった。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu did not miss this opportunity and commanded to put down Yasuyuki as a rebel in May 1389, so Yoritada TOKI and Yorimasu TOKI, father and son, of the Toki clan tried to do it.
Yoshimitsu did not miss this opportunity and commanded to put down Yasuyuki as a rebel in May 1389, so Yoritada TOKI and Yorimasu TOKI, father and son, of the Toki clan tried to do it.
Yoshimitsu did not miss this opportunity and commanded to put down Yasuyuki as a rebel in May 1389, so Yoritada TOKI and Yorimasu TOKI, father and son, of the Toki clan tried to do it.

sen.j: 翌明徳元年（1390年）閏3月に康行は美濃国池田郡小島城（岐阜県揖斐川町）で挙兵するが敗れて没落した。
sen.e: In April 1390, Yasuyuki raised an army in Kojima-jo Castle, Ikeda District, Mino Province (Ibigawa-cho, Gifu Prefecture), but he was defeated and was toppled.
In April 1390, Yasuyuki raised an army in Kojima-jo Castle, Ikeda District, Mino Province (Ibigawa-cho, Gifu Prefecture), but he was defeated and eventually lost his power.
sen.cmt: toppled 転覆したというより力を失った、だと思いますので表現を変えました。
sen.e: In April 1390, Yasuyuki raised an army in Kojima-jo Castle, Ikeda District, Mino Province (Ibigawa-cho, Gifu Prefecture), but he was defeated and eventually lost his power.

sen.j: 戦後
sen.e: After the war
After the war
After the war

sen.j: 康行の美濃国・伊勢国の守護職は没収され、美濃国は戦功のあった土岐頼世（頼忠）、伊勢国は仁木満長へ与えられた。
sen.e: Shugoshiki of Mino Province and Ise Province were took from Yasuyuki, and Yoriyo TOKI (Yoritada) was given Mino Province with his distinguished war service, and Mitsunaga NIKI was given Ise Province.

Yasuyuki lost the status of shugoshiki of Mino and Ise Provinces, and the status for Mino was given to Yoriyo Yoritada) TOKI, who provided excellent services during the war against Yasuyuki, and the status for Ise was given to Mitsunaga NIKI.

Yasuyuki lost the status of shugoshiki of Mino and Ise Provinces, and the status for Mino was given to Yoriyo Yoritada) TOKI, who provided excellent services during the war against Yasuyuki, and the status for Ise was given to Mitsunaga NIKI.

sen.j: 『䕃涼軒日録』によると義満は土岐氏の断絶を考えたが、雲渓支山のとりなしでこれを思い止まり、義満は頼世へ支山に感謝して在所を寄進するよう命じ、頼世は美濃国玉村保を寄進したという。
sen.e: According to " Inryoken Nichiroku" (Inryoken's Diary), it is said that Yoshimitsu thought the extinction of the Toki clan, but Unkei Shizan discouraged him doing this, so Yoshimitsu, by way of appreciation, ordered Yoriyo to donate hometown to Shizan, therefore Yoriyo donated him Tamamura no ho, Mino Province.

According to "Inryoken Nichiroku" (Inryoken's Diary), Yoshimitsu at first thought to end up the family line of the Toki clan, but held back the idea by the intervention of Unkei Shizan, a monk; in the end Yoriyo was ordered by Yoshimitsu to donate some places to the monk as a graditude, and Yoriyo donated Tamamura no ho of the province of Mino.
sen.cmt: 在所。この場合、hometownではないと思います。町に対しての在所、だと思います。与えたところが玉村保、ということは 一部分ということだと思いますのでやはりhometownという感じではないと思います。
sen.e: According to "Inryoken Nichiroku" (Inryoken's Diary), Yoshimitsu at first thought to end up the family line of the Toki clan, but held back the idea by the intervention of Unkei Shizan, a monk; in the end Yoriyo was ordered by Yoshimitsu to donate some places to the monk as a graditude, and Yoriyo donated Tamamura no ho of the province of Mino.

sen.j: 義満の有力守護大名弱体化政策は続けられ、明徳2年（1391年）には11カ国を領して『六分の一殿』と呼ばれた山名氏一族が征伐された（明徳の乱）。
sen.e: It was continued Yoshimitsu's dominant Shugo Guardian Feudal Lord weakening policy, and in 1391, the Yamana family, who dominated 11 provinces and was called "Rokubuno-Ichidono", was conquered (Meitoku War).

Yoshimitsu didn't stop his policy to weaken major shugo daimyo clans, and in 1391, the Yamana family, who had dominated eleven pronices and was even called "Rokubunno-Ichi dono (literally, the lord who has one sixth of the country) was conquered by the Meitoku War.

Yoshimitsu didn't stop his policy to weaken major shugo daimyo clans, and in 1391, the Yamana family, who had dominated eleven pronices and was even called "Rokubunno-Ichi dono (literally, the lord who has one sixth of the country) was conquered by the Meitoku War.

sen.j: 応永6年（1399年）には6カ国の守護だった大内義弘が義満の挑発によって挙兵して滅ぼされた（応永の乱）。
sen.e: In 1399, Yoshihiro OUCHI, shugo of 6 Provinces, raised an army under Yoshimitsu's provocation, but was defeated (Oei War).
In 1399, Yoshihiro OUCHI, a shugo who held six provinces, allowed himself to be provoked into the battle only to be defeated by Yoshimitsu (Oei War).
In 1399, Yoshihiro OUCHI, a shugo who held six provinces, allowed himself to be provoked into the battle only to be defeated by Yoshimitsu (Oei War).

sen.j: 美濃守護職は後に土岐頼益へ譲補され、以後、頼益の家系が土岐氏の惣領として美濃国を支配する。
sen.e: Later, Shugoshiki of Mino was transferred to Yorimasu TOKI and Yorimasu's family line controlled Mino Province as soryo of the Toki clan since then.

Later, the title of shugoshiki of Mino was transferred to Yorimasu TOKI, and from the time onwards his family line became the soryo (chief branch of the family) of the Toki family to govern Mino Province.

Later, the title of shugoshiki of Mino was transferred to Yorimasu TOKI, and from the time onwards his family line became the soryo (chief branch of the family) of the Toki family to govern Mino Province.

sen.j: 康行は明徳2年（1391年）に許されて明徳の乱で戦功を挙げ、応永7年（1400年）に伊勢北半国守護に再任された。
sen.e: Yasuyuki was forgiven in 1391, and by his distinguished war service in Meitoku War, he was reinstated as shugo of Ise Kitahan Province in 1400.
Yasuyuki was forgiven in 1391, and by his distinguished war service in Meitoku War, he was appointed as shugo again, but of the northern half of Ise Province in 1400.
Yasuyuki was forgiven in 1391, and by his distinguished war service in Meitoku War, he was appointed as shugo again, but of the northern half of Ise Province in 1400.

sen.j: 以後、康行の家系は伊勢守護職を継承して土岐世保氏と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Since then, Yasuyuki's family line had been succeeded to Ise Shugoshiki and was called the Toki Yoyasu clan.
Since then, Yasuyuki's family line continuously succeeded the position of shugoshiki of Ise Province and was called themselves as the Toki Yoyasu clan.
Since then, Yasuyuki's family line continuously succeeded the position of shugoshiki of Ise Province and was called themselves as the Toki Yoyasu clan.

sen.j: 満貞は明徳の乱に参戦するが、卑怯な振る舞いがあったと咎められて明徳3年（1392年）に尾張守護職を解任されている。
sen.e: Mitsusada joined the Meitoku war, but he was blamed when he behaved in unfair way, and was dismissed from Owari Shugoshiki in 1392.
Mitsusada joined the Meitoku war, but he was blamed when he behaved in unfair way, and was dismissed from Owari Shugoshiki in 1392.
Mitsusada joined the Meitoku war, but he was blamed when he behaved in unfair way, and was dismissed from Owari Shugoshiki in 1392.

sen.j: 尾張守護職は土岐氏から離れて、応永7年（1400年）以降は斯波氏が継承することになった。
sen.e: Owari shugoshiki came to be succeeded by the Shiba clan since 1400 instead of the Toki clan.
The Toki clan then lost the position of shugoshiki of Owari Province, and was given to the Shiba clan from 1400 onwards.
The Toki clan then lost the position of shugoshiki of Owari Province, and was given to the Shiba clan from 1400 onwards.

sen.j: 乱の発端となった詮直は応永の乱の時に大内義弘に呼応して尾張国で挙兵して美濃国へ討ち入り、美濃守護の土岐頼益に敗れている。
sen.e: In Oei War, Akinao, who was the beginning of the revolt, raised an army in Owari Province agreed with Yoshihiro OUCHI, with the result that he was defeated by Yorimasu TOKI, Mino shugo.

Akinao, who began the first battle of the revolt, raised an army in Owari Province during the Oei War, in response to the movement of Yoshihiro OUCHI, and fought in Mino Province only to lose the battle to Yorimasu TOKI, the shugo of the province.

Akinao, who began the first battle of the revolt, raised an army in Owari Province during the Oei War, in response to the movement of Yoshihiro OUCHI, and fought in Mino Province only to lose the battle to Yorimasu TOKI, the shugo of the province.
